rev.diff:
Line 19: Line 19:
The [[Berkeley Software Distribution]] emerged as an independent Unix-like operating system, with the purging of code copyrighted by AT&T, in the period 1989-1994. During this time various open-source BSD derivatives took shape, starting with [[386BSD]], which was soon succeeded by [[FreeBSD]] and [[NetBSD]]. [[OpenBSD]] emerged in 1995 as a fork of NetBSD.
The [[Berkeley Software Distribution]] emerged as an independent Unix-like operating system, with the purging of code copyrighted by AT&T, in the period 1989-1994. During this time various open-source BSD derivatives took shape, starting with [[386BSD]], which was soon succeeded by [[FreeBSD]] and [[NetBSD]]. [[OpenBSD]] emerged in 1995 as a fork of NetBSD.
â
During BSD's period of legal turmoil, the nearly-complete [[GNU]] operating system was made operational by the inclusion of the [[Linux]] kernel, and countless operating systems, lumped together under the label "Linux", emerged that were based on this combination. (Some, such as GNU Project and [[Free Software Foundation]] founder [[Richard Stallman]], believe that "GNU/Linux" is a more accurate [[GNU/Linux naming controversy|naming convention]], as it is reflects that only the kernel is "Linux", whereas most of the rest of these systems are built on GNU software<ref>http://www.gnu.org/gnu/why-gnu-linux.html</ref>.) Linux derivatives are not compatible enough to qualify for the Unix trademark. On the other hand, BSD systems can at least claim direct ancestry to [[Version 7 Unix]]. Or, according to Open Source advocate Eric Raymond, BSD systems can be considered "genetic Unix", if not "trademark Unix"<ref>http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/print.php/2208691</ref>.
+
During BSD's period of legal turmoil, the nearly-complete [[GNU]] operating system was made operational by the inclusion of the [[Linux]] kernel, and countless operating systems, lumped together under the label "Linux", emerged that were based on this combination. (Some, such as GNU Project and [[Free Software Foundation]] founder [[Richard Stallman]], believe that "GNU/Linux" is a more accurate [[GNU/Linux naming controversy|naming convention]], as it is reflects that only the kernel is "Linux", whereas most of the rest of these systems are built on GNU software<ref>http://www.gnu.org/gnu/why-gnu-linux.html</ref>.) Linux derivatives are not compatible enough to qualify for the Unix trademark. On the other hand, BSD systems can at least claim direct ancestry to [[Version 7 Unix]]. Or, according to Open Source advocate [[Eric Raymond]], BSD systems can be considered "genetic Unix", if not "trademark Unix"<ref>http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/print.php/2208691</ref>.
[[Mac OS X v10.5]] is the first operating system with open source BSD code to be certified as fully Unix compliant<ref>[http://www.opengroup.org/comm/press/19-2-nov07.htm Mac OS X Leopard Achieves UNIX 03 Product Standard Certification]</ref>.
[[Mac OS X v10.5]] is the first operating system with open source BSD code to be certified as fully Unix compliant<ref>[http://www.opengroup.org/comm/press/19-2-nov07.htm Mac OS X Leopard Achieves UNIX 03 Product Standard Certification]</ref>.
